notice pursuant to s. 155 of the act

commission's "reason to believe" that a person is capable of furnishing information, producing documents or giving evidence relating to a matter that constitutes or may constitute a contravention of the act."  practice and procedure
"fishing expedition".  trade practices act 1974 (cth.) s. 155  trade practices
whether chairman had reason to believe referred to therein
whether in proceedings party challenging validity of notice entitled to discovery and interrogatories as to chairman's reason to believe

fishing. the respondent chairman of the trade practices commission issued a notice pursuant to s. 155 of the trade practices act 1974 directed to the applicant requiring it to furnish information and produce documents. in the notice the respondent recited, in accordance with the terms of s. 155 , that he had reason to believe that the applicant was capable of furnishing information and producing documents relating to a matter "that constitutes or may constitute a contravention" of the act. by application pursuant to s. 163a of the act, the applicant sought declarations that the notice was ineffective. its statement of claim contained an allegation that the respondent did not have the requisite reason to believe the matters referred to in s. 155 and recited in the notice. it also alleged that the lack of definition of the respondent's belief as recited in the notice was inconsistent with the belief required by s. 155. toohey j. ordered that this last allegation be struck out as disclosing no reasonable cause of action, but refused to order that the allegation of non-existence of the chairman's reason to believe be struck out. the appellant had sought disovery and leave to interrogate as to this issue. toohey j. refused to make such orders. on appeal,  held: dismissing the appeal, and allowing the cross appeal

(1) the allegation in the statement of claim that the chairman did not have the requisite reason to believe should be struck out as an abuse of the process of the court as an unsubstantiated assertion that could not be substantiated.
power of commission to obtain information, documents and evidence

trade practices act 1974 (cth.), ss. 155 , 163a. each of the applicants received a notice issued under s. 155 of the trade practices act 1974 from the second-named respondent requiring the furnishing of information and production of documents in relation to suspected breaches of s. 45 of the act by the addressee of the notice.  the applicants commenced proceedings under s. 163a of the act seeking declarations that the notices did not oblige the applicants to answer questions or deliver documents which might tend to expose them to a penalty, did not oblige the applicants to comply with the requirements of the notice and were void and of no effect. the applicants also sought leave to deliver interrogatories and a notice for discovery limited to the question of whether the second-named respondent had any and what reason to believe that the respondents were capable of furnishing the information or documents referred to in the notices. it was contended for the respondents that no such leave should be given and that the reasons of the second-named respondent were not examinable.  smithers j. stated a case pursuant to s. 25 (6) of the federal court of australia act 1976 for the opinion of the full court.  held: per curiam

the applicants were lawfully required under s. 155 to answer questions, provide information or produce documents which might tend to expose them to a penalty under ss. 45 and 76 of the act. the privilege against exposure to a penalty has been abrogated by the provisions contained in s. 155.

high court rules, o. 19, rr. 1, 6, 7; o. 20, rr. 5, 6, 8, 29; o. 26, r. 18; o. 63, r. 2. the plaintiff sought to have declared void an arbitration clause in its contract with the defendant, n. the contract was in a standard form as stipulated by the master builders association ("the mba") for its members including the defendant, n. the contract was alleged to be made pursuant to contracts, arrangements or understandings between the defendants, including the australian institute of building ("aib"), to provide for the elimination of competition in contravention of the trade practices act 1974-1977, ss. 45 and 46. aib applied for the action against it to be dismissed or perpetually stayed on the grounds that the statement of claim did not disclose a reasonable cause of action and that the action against it was frivolous and vexatious or an abuse of the process of the court.

cost of photocopying discovered documents  applicant/respondent to cross claim shetland nominees pty ltd (acn 005 352 698) t/as choice cabinets respondent/applicant by cross claim glenvill pty ltd (acn 007 034 451) where held melbourne before deputy president c aird hearing type directions hearing date of hearing 7 october 2009 date of order 13 october 2009 citation shetland nominees pty ltd tas choice cabinets v glenvill pty ltd (domestic building) [2009] vcat 2192  order  declare the agreed rate for providing photocopies of discovered documents, other than those which fall into a special category, is $0.30 per page plus gst. declare the $1.10 per page charged for photocopying by kalus kenny, glenvill's solicitors, in its tax invoice dated 1 october 2009, is excessive, and direct kalus kenny to withdraw it and re-issue such tax invoice at the rate of $0.30 per page plus gst. liberty to apply until 4:00pm on 19 october 2009, including to apply by consent in writing for the proceeding to be referred to a further compulsory conference. costs reserved
